enrichment.AboutCourse:
This course will train you to become a history teacher across the 11-16 or 11-18 age range. It will prepare you to teach the National Curriculum and related national strategies at GCSE and A level. Completion of this ten-month course leads to both a postgraduate qualification and qualified teacher status (QTS), as well as up to 60 master's-level credits towards further study.\r
\r
The course combines master's level academic study of history education with a range of school experiences. Approximately two-thirds of your time will be spent in our partnership schools and colleges developing your practical teaching skills with the support of trained history mentors and experienced teachers. When on placement, you will observe and teach classes under the guidance of an experienced history teacher mentor, improving your skills in planning, teaching and assessment.\r
enrichment.Qualifications:
- Minimum 2:1 honours degree in history or a related subject. A minimum of 50% of your degree content should be history related (if you are unsure, please contact us to discuss your qualifications).\r
- 104 UCAS points including a B in history or a related subject at A-level, excluding AS-levels, General Studies, and counting your three best A-level grades (or equivalent qualifications). \r
- Minimum grade C or 4 at GCSE (or equivalent) in English language and mathematics.\r
enrichment.HowSchoolPlacementsWork:
The course is a partnership between the University and schools and colleges drawn from a wide area, including Bolton, Bury, Cheshire, Deeside, Lancashire, Manchester, Merseyside, Oldham, Rochdale, Salford, Staffordshire, Stockport, Tameside, Trafford, Warrington and Wigan. In your placement schools and colleges, you will observe and teach classes under the guidance of experienced subject mentors.\r
\r
As a trainee teacher you'll spend two-thirds of your course in schools or colleges, and the remaining time in University-based study.\r
\r
We maintain close contact with our partnership establishments at every stage of the programme. These include:\r
\r
11-18 and 11-16 comprehensive and independent schools\r
city academies\r
further education colleges\r
sixth-form colleges\r
specialist schools (e.g technology colleges, arts colleges).\r
\r
As a trainee teacher you'll spend two-thirds of your course in schools or colleges, and the remaining time in University-based study. In your placement schools and colleges, you will observe and teach classes under the guidance of experienced subject mentors.\r
\r
Both your mentors and tutors will help you to record your achievements and set targets. During each placement, a University tutor will observe you teach, and at the end of each school experience, you will receive a report from your mentor. The report will grade you in the following areas:   \r
\r
teaching\r
planning\r
differentiation and assessment\r
learning environment\r
wider professional responsibilities. \r
\r
The grades are awarded by your mentor in conjunction with your University tutor. These reports, together with your record of achievement and development, facilitate your progression as a teacher.\r
